data.title: Oracle Corporation (ORCL) Dividend Date & History
data.meta_description: The last Oracle Corporation (ORCL) ex-dividend date: Jul 11, 2024. Detailed view of Oracle Corporation (ORCL) dividend date & history, payout ratio and more on Koyfin
data.text:
Dividend Data

Oracle Corporationâs (ORCL) dividend yield is 1.14%, which means that for every $100 invested in the company's stock, investors would receive $1.14 in dividends per year.

Oracle Corporationâs payout ratio is 41.95% which means that 41.95% of the company's earnings are paid out as dividends. A low payout ratio may indicate that the company has a strong financial position and can invest in growth opportunities, while a high payout ratio may indicate that the company is returning most of its earnings to shareholders. ORCLâs annual dividend is $1.60 per share. This is the total amount of dividends paid out to shareholders in a year.

Oracle Corporationâs (ORCL) ex-dividend date is July 11, 2024, which means that buyers purchasing shares on or after that date will not be eligible to receive the next dividend payment.

Oracle Corporation (ORCL) pays dividends on a quarterly basis. The next dividend payment is planned on July 25, 2024. Oracle Corporation (ORCL) has increased its dividends for 10 consecutive years. This is a positive sign of the company's financial stability and its ability to pay consistent dividends in the future.

Shareholder Yield

Shareholder yield is a metric that measures the total return to shareholders through dividends, buybacks, and debt paydown. It is a ratio that compares the cash returned to shareholders over a period of time to the market capitalization of the company.

Oracle Corporation (ORCL) shareholder yield graph below includes indicators for dividends, buybacks, and debt paydown, which allows investors to see how each component contributes to the overall shareholder yield.

It's important to note that shareholder yield is just one metric among many that investors may use to evaluate a company's financial health and its potential for future growth. It should be considered in conjunction with other financial metrics such as earnings, revenue, and debt levels to get a comprehensive understanding of a company's financial position.

Dividend Safety

Dividend safety refers to the ability of a company to continue paying its dividends to shareholders without interruption or reduction. A company with a high level of dividend safety is generally considered to have a strong financial position, with a consistent history of paying dividends and a low risk of default.

Some specific indicators often used to assess Oracle Corporation (ORCL) dividend safety include

Dividend payment history: ORCL has a long history of paying dividends and has consistently increased its dividend payout for 10 consecutive years.

Dividend payout ratio: A low payout ratio, typically less than 60%, indicates that a company has enough earnings to pay dividends and retain earnings to reinvest in the business. Oracle Corporationâs payout ratio is about 41.95%

It is worth noting that Dividend safety can change over time, and a company that was considered to have a high level of dividend safety in the past may no longer be considered safe today. Therefore, it is important to regularly monitor a company's financial performance and dividend payment history.
